questions.question_text: Which of the following are the MOST important items to include in the final report for a penetration test? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
In Comptia certmaster states: Conclusion: This section wraps up the report. It should include a general summary statement about failures and successes, with supporting evidence that can be written in a sentence or two. It should also include a statement of the PenTest goals and whether those goals were met. You can get more specific about potential attacks and what assets such an attack could leverage. Identify the areas that are most likely to be compromised and recommend that those be dealt with as soon as possible.

Selected Answer: AF
I will go with A & F 
https://cobalt.io/blog/how-to-write-an-effective-pentest-report-vulnerability-reports

Selected Answer: AC
Including the vulnerability identifier is crucial for clear identification and reference of the specific vulnerabilities discovered during the penetration test. This helps the client and other stakeholders easily understand and track the identified issues.

Including the CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System) score of the findings provides an objective measure of the severity and potential impact of the vulnerabilities. This scoring system allows the client to prioritize and address the identified vulnerabilities based on their severity levels.

Selected Answer: CF
I think

comments.content: CONCUERDO CONTIGO ES A Y C

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A. The CVSS score of the finding and C. The vulnerability identifier. The CVSS score is important for providing an indication of the severity of the vulnerability and its potential impact. The vulnerability identifier is important for providing a way to cross reference the finding with other sources of information and for tracking the progress of remediation efforts.

Selected Answer: BC
I agree with @Setsunarcangel..... why would it matter what tools were used to find the vulnerabilities guys? Companies don't care if you used nmap or angry ip-scanner...? All they care is what is the vulnerability, where is it, how do we fix it, etc. D, E, F ARE OUT right off the bat. A, B, C, are left. A, the CVSS score, is not helpful with only the score, the CVE will be helpful, and will include CVSS score, but CVSS score alone will not help them to remediate, they need to IDENTIFY the vulnerability WHAT and WHERE.
I think it should be B and F
I would go with A and F on this one.

choices.B: The network location of the vulnerable device
choices.E: The name of the person who found the flaw
choices.A: The CVSS score of the finding
choices.F: The tool used to find the issue

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are a security analyst tasked with hardening a web server.
You have been given a list of HTTP payloads that were flagged as malicious.

INSTRUCTIONS -
Given the following attack signatures, determine the attack type, and then identify the associated remediation to prevent the attack in the future.
If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
1. Dom XSS - input san. <,> https://portswigger.net/web-security/cross-site-scripting/dom-based
2. SQLi Stacked - Parameterized Queries
3. SQLi Union - Parameterized Queries
4. Reflected XSS - input san <,> https://portswigger.net/web-security/cross-site-scripting/reflected
5. SQLi Error - Parameterized Queries https://www.indusface.com/blog/types-of-sql-injection/#Error_Based_SQL_Injection
6. CMD Injection - Input San. /,\ Sandbox
7. URL Redirect - Prevent ext. calls
8. local file inclusion - Input san. /,\ Sandbox
9. CMD Injection - input san. [,],(,)
10. Remote File Inclusion - input san. /,\ Sandbox

comments.content:
For Payload 1. #inner-tab"><script>alert(1)</script>

Given: "You are a security analyst tasked with hardening a web server." 
Since the focus is on server hardening, addressing server-side vulnerabilities like Reflected XSS would be the main priority. Therefore, it's safe to conclude that Reflected XSS is the more appropriate choice in this server-focused context.
Thank you for your time and effort, this is definitely the best answer there is
Verified everyone in the book and looked up all the ASCII chars. Good to go. Thanks for making that one easy.

8) logfile=%2fetc%2fpasswd%00
Decoded is : logfile=/etc/passwd and at the end %00 terminate the string to ignore if the application will append something else.
In the real world we have to validate input, limit priviledge, use secure API, escaping of input and query parameterizing.
Solution: input sanization / and \ so we can’t browse across directory, but also a “sandbox requests” to deny access to specific resources of the operating system.

2) item=widget';waitfor%20delay%20'00:00:20';--
That’s an example of SQL Injection, for many reason, one of them because we see double dash that means “from here a comment” in SQL.
SQL Injection is a technique that exploits a webapp that not sanifies property the user input.
In this situation the attacker is injecting an SQL instruction: WAITFOR DELAY '00:00:20'
The “stacked” word in “SQL Injection Stacked” means the attacker is trying to stack more SQL instructions in one single query.
Solution: Parameterized queries
(in a real situation, I can’t accept that a database webuser should be granted to execute this kind of queries…)

4) search=Bob”%3e%3cimg%20src%3da%20onerror%3dalert(1)%3e
After decoding will be interpreted as: s e a r c h = B o b " > < i m g s r c = a 
 o n e r r o r = a l e r t ( 1 ) > 
In this case the attacker is inserting a picture with img tag, but the picture can’t be loaded because “a” is a not valid link, that’s why the on error event will be activated executing the 
 a l e r t ( 1 ) f u n c t i o n.
So that’s a Reflected XSS: when an application receives data in an HTTP request and includes that data within the immediate response in a unsafe way.
 Ig: search?term=gift
And the application echoes the supplied search term in the response
You searched for: gift

Solution: A solution can be to prevent the inclusion of tag ( deny “<” and “>” ) with an input sanization

6) site=www.exa’pi.ng%20-c%2010%20localhost’mple.com
Decoding is: site=www.exapi.ng -c 10 localhostmple.com => site=www.exa(ping -c 10 localhost)mple.com
That’s an example of command injection, we can recognize it because it is using operating systems commands’ (“p.ing”).

Solution: In this question the solution answer should be sandboxing.
Sandboxing means to isolate a process or an application in a secure environment called “sandbox” to limit interaction with the system. A sandbox typically has limited access to system files, is limited on quantity of memory/CPU to use, can’t interact with other applications or processes unless it explicitly allowed, can’t access to the network unless explicitly allowed.
Small consideration: in a real scenario I’m not sure about the input sanization of char / in an URL could have no side effects.

discussion.content:
1) #Inner-Tab = DOM XSS - Input sanitization (<> ...) Explanation: “inner-tab” is a CSS id-selector and can be used to identify in unique way an element in your HTML code. It could be something like:
Some content inside here
The code maybe use something like Or in jquery: $('#inner-tab').hide(); And you could attack via XSS injecting a DOM: Solution: input sanization of < and > will help to not include HTML tags.

This PBQ reminds me of the Star Trek: The Kobayashi Maru, No-Win Scenario. 
Knowing the answer 100% seems like the no-win scenario. 

## PAYLOADS VULNERABILITY TYPE. REMEDIATION 
01 #Inner-Tab = DOM XSS - Input sanitization (<> ...)
02 Item=Widget = SQL Injection STACKED - Parameterized Queries
03 Item=Widget%20. = SQLi UNION - Parameterized Queries
04 Search=BOB = Reflected XSS. - Input sanitization (<> ...)
05 Item widget+ convert = SQLi error - Parameterized Queries
06 Site = www. Exa = Command Injection - Sandbox Requests
07 Redirect http: = URL redirect - Preventing External Calls
08 Logfile=%2 = Local File Inclusion - Input Sanitization $ 
09 Lookup =$(whoami) = Command Injection - Input Sanitization $ [] ()
10 Logfile =http = 2% = Remote File Inclusion - Input Sanitization /,\ Sandbox

Inner Tab = Reflected XSS - Input sanitization (<> ...) 
Item= widget = Sql Injection (Stacked) - Parameterized Queries 
Item=widget%20.= DOM XSS - Input Sanitization (<> ...) 
Search=BOB = Local File Inclusion - sandbox req 
Item widget+ convert = Command Injection - sandbox req
Site = www. Exa = SQLi (union) - paramtrized queries 
Redirect http : . SQLi (error) - paramtrized queries 
Log file =2% Remote File Inclusion – sandbox
Lookup =$ = Command Injection - input saniti $ []
Logfile =http = 2% URL redirect - prevent external calls

The correct answer is:
1. Reflected XSS - Input sanitization (<> ...)
2. Sql Injection Stacked - Parameterized Queries
3. DOM XSS - Input Sanitization (<> ...)
4. Local File Inclusion - sandbox req
5. Command Injection - sandbox req
6. SQLi union - paramtrized queries
7. SQLi error - paramtrized queries
8. Remote File Inclusion - sandbox
9. Command Injection - input saniti $
10. URL redirect - prevent external calls

You are completely right, thank you for putting in the work.

discussion.content: There is so much wrong with the revealed answer here that it's a bit much to type all of it out.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester runs the unshadow command on a machine. Which of the following tools will the tester most likely use NEXT?

discussion.content:
A.
Jtr is a tool for you to crack your hashes. The unshadow command will combine /etc/shadow (where your hashes are stored) and /etc/passwd (list of users found) into one output than you can feed into jtr.

Selected Answer: A
The "unshadow" command is typically used to combine the /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow files on Unix-like systems, creating a single file with hashed passwords that can be used for offline password cracking. By running this command, the tester retrieves the hashed password data, which can then be subjected to password cracking techniques.
John the Ripper and Hashcat are both popular password-cracking tools commonly used by penetration testers. These tools utilize various methods, including dictionary-based attacks, brute force attacks, and rainbow table attacks, to attempt to crack the hashed passwords and reveal the plaintext passwords.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester has been hired to configure and conduct authenticated scans of all the servers on a software company's network. Which of the following accounts should the tester use to return the MOST results?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Local Administrator is a trick and here's why it can't be the answer: They want to scan ALL assets, and unless you had the same local username and password (bad) then you'd have to enter a lot of credentials to scan all the assets.

Selected Answer: C
I'll go with C although it doesn't specifically states that it would be a privileged service account.
Service accounts are a special type of non-human privileged account used to execute applications and run automated services, virtual machine instances, and other processes. Service accounts can be privileged local or domain accounts, and in some cases, they may have domain administrative privileges.
https://www.beyondtrust.com/blog/entry/how-to-manage-and-secure-service-accounts-best-practices

Now, this is one of those questions which are not clear.
I think C is not correct. 
A service account does not have administrative privileges to perform authenticated scans.
I would take B in this case.
